title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "This project will monitor the recovery of the tiger and its prey base in Manas National Park. This would be done by a) estimating tiger population densities in the Park using photographic captures and recaptures, b) estimating the densities of key large mammal herbivores that constitute prey species of the tiger in the Park using line transect sampling, and c) sustaining the monitoring and research program on vegetation dynamics in the Park to inform habitat management...Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) carry out camera trapping in six blocks of the Park over three camera trapping sessions (1.5 to 2.0 months per session) using 30-40 camera trap locations per block; (2) construct capture histories for each adult tiger and analyze these histories using CAPTURE to estimate abundance; (3) carry out line transect sampling to estimate tiger prey densities using 2 km long transects in all three ranges located in areas where camera traps are located; (4) analyze the count and distance data obtained from the transect sampling using the program DISTANCE; (5) install over 120 permanent vegetation quadrats of 30 m X 30 m size each spread across the entire landscape of the park and assess these plots for woody plant species; (6) conduct a one-time soil sampling in each plant quadrat and assess soil physical and chemical parameters; and (7) utilize the vegetation data to (a) develop a supervised land cover classification using high resolution satellite imagery, (b) characterize the distribution of plant species and diversity across the MNP landscape, and (c) develop a spatially explicit model of the environmental determinants of vegetation type and vegetation change in a GIS framework.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to carry out experimental habitat restoration for Asian elephants in Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary in India. During the first phase recipient will conduct surveys and small-scale experiments to identify 10 sites where Lantana is densest, where long-term restoration will be initiated. The first experiment will identify one of a few commonly practiced mechanical removal methods cutting, uprooting, and the recently developed Cut Root Stock (CSR) technique. The second experiment will identify 3 native forage plants which have the highest rates of germination and survival in plots where Lantana has been removed. These species will be used for the assisted regeneration step of the second phase. The second phase will consist of clearing Lantana in 1-ha plots at each of the 10 sites identified in the survey, using the mechanical removal method identified in the first experiment. The clearing will be followed by the assisted regeneration of native plants by planting seeds of the three species identified in the second experiment. All other plants will be allowed to naturally regenerate. The third and last phase will consist of monitoring the recovery of the understory.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Developing a comprehensive conservation strategy for tigers (Panthera tigris) and their prey in the Central Terai Landscape, India

description.narrative: This grant will establish the scientific foundation needed for a comprehensive conservation strategy for tigers and their prey in the Central Terai Landscape (CTL) of India and then support preparation of that strategy. The Recipient will do this by: (1) continuing to assess the status of tiger and prey populations across a human disturbance gradient represented by Pilibhit Reserve Forest, Dudhwa National Park, Kishanpur Wildlife Sanctuary, Katerniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary and the Nandhour region using state-of-the art survey designs and mark-recapture statistical estimators; (2) recapturing individual tigers in order to determine inter-annual movement distances in areas surveyed with camera traps in Year 1 of the project; (3) estimating functional connectivity across the CTL (from Gola River to Katerniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary) in order to identify key corridors and movement barriers in the Haldwani Pilibhit -Kishanpur - Dudhwa - Katerniaghat Forest complex; and (4) synthesizing information from the above 3 objectives into a comprehensive tiger conservation strategy for the CTL.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to secure the elephant corridor and prevent further degradation, and regain the willingness of community participation, in eastern part of Chirang-Ripu Elephant Reserve through plantation, monitoring the movement of elephants in fragmented habitat, implementation of diversified human-elephant conflict (HEC) mitigation measures (e.g. trip wire, electric fence, chili-based deterrents, watchtowers, lights), and motivating and changing the livelihood of forest dependent families by creating diversified livelihood options, educational events such as camps among school students, teachers training, wildlife film shows etc. Awareness among the community will increase the level of confidence among the villagers for living in harmony with elephants.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to achieve conservation of the Northern Karnataka elephant population through mitigation of human-elephant conflict (HEC) and knowledge-based conservation planning. By reducing crop damage in the project area applicant hopes to raise the tolerance of farmers to elephant presence and contribute to conservation of elephants. HEC is expected to increase in coming years given that many farmers in the project area are taking up sugarcane cultivation. Applicant will carry out experiments on low cost elephant deterrent measures and implement them with the involvement of local people. Objectives include, (1) implementation of Community-based Conflict Management (CBCM) in affected villages with involvement of local farmers and capacity building of the farmers in implementation of these measures, (2) carrying out experiments to assess the effectiveness of low-cost mitigation measures on captive elephants, (3) creating a database of wild elephants in the project area by building visual identification key for each elephant, (4) mapping and assessing quality of habitat for elephants and identification and assessment of corridors in Belgaum Division, (5) extension programs for creating awareness on CBCM model and elephant conservation.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to raise awareness about the need to conserve tigers among communities, teachers, and students living on the periphery of these tiger habitats so they may play a role in reducing human-tiger conflict. This will be done by: (1) conducting four three day Teachers for Tigers (T4T) extension training workshops at four different locations in Uttarakhand; (2) encouraging, supporting with resource materials, and tracking conduct of tiger education activities by T4T trained teachers; (3) providing T4T trained teachers with a tiger awareness education kit; (4) conducting capacity building training programs for three HTC affected communities; (5) conducting tiger conservation education programs for the Van guijar, Kanjar and Bawariya communities (which have past history of community members participating in poaching, one program per community) as well as for the local tiger safari jeep drivers; and (6) providing teachers at Nainital and Kotdwar who received T4T training earlier with special one-day leadership training on organizing student tiger awareness campaign rallies and guide them in carrying out 3 such rallies.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce retaliatory killing of elephants within the project area to around 50% of 2013 levels, and build public awareness for long term peaceful coexistence between man and elephant. Grantee will build capacity within human-elephant conflict (HEC) affected villages in Nepal and West Bengal by creating village protection committees and anti-depredation squads, enhance the capacity of these communities to address HEC, build bio-fences to keep out migrating elephants, conduct awareness campaigns on elephants, HEC and mitigation measures through meetings and banners/leaflets in local languages.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build on the background research and extensive experience that Elephant Family, the Wildlife Protection Society of India (WPSI) and the Wildlife Society of Odisha (WSO) have generated through working in partnership since 2005. Applicant will engage local communities in conservation by providing support, advice and information through regular meetings and one large workshop. Four local wildlife conservation groups will be empowered to raise awareness, attract new members and help the Forest Department intervene when illegal activity is posing a threat to elephants, while also alerting the project team to other threats to elephants in their area. Threats from industrial activity will result in dialogue with the company responsible. This approach has proved effective in the past and will be extended to tackle further threats, such as the deaths of elephants by electrocution from low-hanging power cables, which is an issue on which the three partner organizations have been working on for the past two years. HEC mitigation assistance will be provided to 30 villages. The project will also sustain an awareness program and forest protection committees at Simlipal National Park.

This will be carried out in 3 forest divisions.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to improve protection, management and connectivity of protected areas in this landscape so as to ensure the demographic and genetic viability of this tiger population. This will be done by: (1) reviewing existing enforcement systems and capacity culminating in a two day workshop with Forest Department and Police Department representatives during which the existing enforcement system will be critically assessed and strategies to strengthen protection will be tabled; (2) building the capacity of enforcement personnel in the Karauli Division of Ranthambhore Tiger Reserve, Kuno Wildlife Division and Madhav National Park (8 workshops to train 500 forest frontline staff); (3) carrying out ground surveys in all four corridors as well as the adjoining areas of Ranthambhore Tiger Reserve collecting data on encounters with carnivore and prey sign, human disturbance sign and habitat status; (4) determining tiger and other large carnivore occupancy and estimate prey abundance in corridors and the buffer of Ranthambhore Tiger Reserve; (5) determining tiger abundance using the camera trap based mark-recapture method; (6) implementing an interim human tiger conflict relief scheme in the corridor areas and buffer of Ranthambhore Tiger Reserve; and (7) monitoring livestock kills in the corridors and buffer of Tanthambhore tiger Reserve through camera trapping to determine which large predators are most likely to be involved in such kills..."

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to: 1) Develop a website to serve as a public outreach, communication and education point for the program and for a broader regional and international audience seeking Asian elephant conservation education resources; 2) Conduct HEC education and planning workshops in Bhutan and India for >35 educators, policymakers, researchers, forest officials, and other stakeholders. In these workshops (one in Gelephu, Bhutan and one in Assam, India) we will assess the available data on HEC incidences and prevention strategies, develop collaborative community-based programs to reduce HEC and promote elephant habitat conservation, and train educators (initially in Bhutan) to conduct village outreach using the Elephants Trunk (previously supported by USFWS/AsECF) project; 3) Hold a kickoff meeting and 5 additional meetings with Tea Garden representatives from the regions hardest-hit HEC areas, to develop and implement a Tea Garden Elephant Conservation Program, including certification for Elephant-friendly tea garden management practices; 4) Establish, train and implement a pilot HEC Rapid Response Team comprising local volunteers from 25 villages identified as having high levels of HEC (Odalguri District). Volunteers will conduct elephant watch programs and issue communication alerts when elephants are approaching villages or HEC incidents have occurred; 5) Implement an Early Warning System demonstration program at three HEC-prone sites, with installation and ongoing maintenance commitments from local villagers and project partners; 6) Adapt and promote the Elephants Trunk for use with school groups, student clubs, and villagers in Assam, India; 7) Conduct an Ele-Photo training to engage 10 youth from high HEC communities as photography leaders. The youth leaders will work within their communities to engage children in photojournalism projects on HEC, elephants, and affected villages; 8) Develop and pilot an Ambassador Elephant Program

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to establish local capacity within governmental and non-governmental sectors to effectively monitor and conserve tiger and prey populations. This will be done by: 1) training and empowering local forest department personnel in rigorous monitoring of tigers through camera trap based capture-recapture sampling and monitoring of prey through line transect based Distance sampling in Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary; 2) collaborating with other organizations with similar conservation agendas active in Kerala to build local capacity through intensive training in field survey activities, workshops and awareness programs; and 3) proactively involving members of the civil society in tiger prey estimation and monitoring activities.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to strengthen anti-poaching efforts in a corridor, North Karbi Anglong Wildlife Sanctuary, used by tigers and other large mammals to flee flooding in Kaziranga National Park. This will be done by (1) developing needed infrastructure and improving mobility and surveillance capabilities including constructing a new forest office and camp, providing a vehicle for patrolling, constructing a deep well bore for drinking water, and providing solar power lights and equipment for charging batteries; (2) equipping 25 front line forest staff with basic field materials needed to enhance their anti-poaching/anti-smuggling patrols and reporting activities including field uniforms, torches, shoes, leech guards, rain gear, batteries, GPS units, digital cameras, laptop and search lights; (3) forming one mobile patrolling party; (4) introducing MIST based SMART patrol techniques on a pilot basis to the front line forest staff by providing 15-20 forest staff with a 7 day intensive training program; and (5) initiating a community outreach program by presenting 10 school level awareness camps and 5 community level outreach programs.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to increase capacity of the staff of the Forest Department of Assam to carry out effective anti-poaching protection and prevention measures; (2) increase capacity of forest staff to implement professional and safe investigative and enforcement techniques; and (3) increase the number of successful wildlife convictions against poachers and traffickers. This will be done by: (1) consulting with the Assam Forest Department management staff to select modules from the PROTECT and DETECT training programs to ensure maximum relevance for field staff; (2) preparing resource materials for trainees; (3) training 25 to 75 of the junior most patrol staff (Forest Guards) and their immediate supervisors (Foresters and Range Forest Officers) drawn from important rhino and/or tiger sites; (4) preparing a quick reference booklet of enforcement procedures: (5) translating manuals into local languages; (6) preparing a final report for sharing with management of the protected area; and (8) publicizing the completed trainings on the FREELAND website. As planning for this training program proceeds emphasis will be placed on training trainers so the Forest Department will be able to effectively pass on the knowledge provided through the course.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to train the lower levels of the Assam Forest Departments field staff in wildlife conservation and habitat management with emphasis on conservation of rhinos, tigers, elephants and gibbons. This will be done by providing training on wildlife and habitat conservation; SMART patrol techniques; human-animal conflict mitigation; and power fence erection, use and maintenance for conflict reduction. A 21 day course (including SMART training) will be provided to the staffs of R.G. Orang, Nameri, and Dibru Saikhowa national parks and Laokhowa Bura Chapori Wildlife Sanctuaries; and an 11 day course (not including SMART training) will be provided to the field staffs of Kaziranga and Manas national parks.

title.narrative: Forest Department-Community partnership to improve protection of..Western Hoolock Gibbons Hoolock hoolock in Jeypore RF, Phase-III.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to involve the Forest Department and local people in further protecting one of Indias most viable gibbon populations. This will be done by: 1) continuing conduct of regular patrols according to SMART protocols with no fewer than 15 day of active patrolling per month and at least one river patrol per week; 2) systematically recording patrol details and producing monthly reports, and planning future patrols using these reports; 3) training the roving gibbon patrol units in SMART patrol PHASE III and gibbon conservation; and 5) working with the Police Department and/or Army to have them provide the patrol teams with additional law enforcement training.

title.narrative: Training of Forest Guards for the Conservation of Hoolock Gibbon in Assam, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is the long term conservation of hoolock gibbons and their habitat in Assam by producing a group of trained, skilled and motivated forest guards who can take up the difficult task of protection and conservation by involving local human communities. Forest Guards who work in gibbon habitats will be educated on methods used to protect gibbons, the identification of various species of gibbons, gibbon survey techniques, legal protection available for gibbons, the population status and threats to the survival of gibbons, and the value and ethics of wildlife conservation and the need to bring about an attitudinal change among forest staff and the community at large. Specifically, this will be done by: providing training to 100 Forest Guards posted in habitats occupied by hoolock gibbons; carrying out five - 7 day intensive, residential courses on hoolock gibbon conservation comprised of lectures, seminars, group discussions, individual and group assignments and field study at the Gibbon Wildlife Sanctuary; and carrying out a pre- and post- training assessment of the knowledge and attitudinal change resulting from the course in the various trainees.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Landscape genetics of three Asian elephant populations in the Western Ghats, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to map the genetic diversity, local effective population size, and landscape connectivity of wild Asian elephant populations in three elephant ranges of the Western Ghats, Tamil Nadu, India. The recipient will: 1) create a DNA profile database of individual elephants that will be shared with the Forest Department for forensic research; 2) quantify and map spatial patterns of genetic diversity across the population; 3) estimate local effective population sizes using molecular methods; 4) use landscape genetic modeling approaches to identify factors that control gene flow and population connectivity; 5) develop spatially-optimized management alternatives to maximize the protection of population connectivity; 6) predict relationships between population connectivity, genetic diversity, and effective population size; and 7) identify core habitats and corridors using landscape pattern analysis software. This project will contribute to the conservation of the Asian elephant by providing spatially explicit, empirically-based, and scientifically rigorous knowledge to the Forest Department to use in planning and implementing effective elephant conservation programs.

title.narrative: Assessing the status of adult male Asian elephant populations in Nagarahole-Bandipur National Parks, Karnataka, lndia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the adult male and overall population status of Asian elephants across Nagarhole-Bandipur National Parks in Karnataka, southwestern India, and will develop and contribute to a rigorous scientific monitoring program for elephants in Karnataka. Project activities will include: 1) creation of a photographic database for adult male elephants for photo-identification of individuals; 2) estimation of the population abundance of male elephants by using capture-recapture analyses and related parameters from photographs; 3) estimation of total elephant population using line-transect surveys under a distance-sampling framework; and 4) training of Forest Department personnel in monitoring methods by way of field workshops, training modules, and production of training materials on field monitoring protocols and elephant conservation topics. This project, the first step in establishing a scientific elephant population monitoring program in the region, will allow evaluation of on-the-ground impacts of recent surges in ivory poaching, directly inform park managers of the results of anti-poaching and other conservation efforts, enable managers to identify conflict animals, and enhance local capacity for elephant conservation.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Facilitating movement permeability for the conflict-prone Asian elephant in a human-dominated landscape, Assam, lndia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate human-elephant conflict mitigation and landscape connectivity for Asian elephants in the Kaziranga-Karbi Anglong landscape in Assam, northeast India. This project will contribute to a thriving elephant population and ensure that the population is able to safely and routinely undertake their natural annual migrations in this unique floodplain ecosystem. Project activities will include: 1) prioritization of areas which are important for connectivity between Kaziranga and Karbi Anglong by conducting occupancy surveys during pre- and post-flood seasons to assess the maximal use and permeability of the landscape by elephants and by conducting a connectivity prioritization exercise to identify areas of high importance for movement during flooding; 2) identification and inclusion of stakeholders in the implementation of movement-friendly conflict mitigation strategies by mapping landholdings, conducting questionnaire-based surveys on human-elephant conflict, and assessing the potential of mitigation measures to act as barriers to elephant movement; and 3) design and implementation of elephant movement-friendly conflict mitigation measures by assessing the willingness of stakeholders to modify mitigation strategies, and formulate and initiate an action plan on movement-friendly strategies. This project will establish a participatory conservation program that will facilitate seasonal elephant movement critical in this floodplain ecosystem, while simultaneously mitigating human-elephant conflict.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Augmenting stakeholder awareness on Asian elephant conservation in human-elephant conflict areas of Tamil Nadu, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conduct human-elephant conflict (HEC) capacity-building and awareness programs in HEC-affected villages of Coimbatore and Hosur Forest Departments of Tamil Nadu, India. This project will promote best practices for HEC-mitigation via a sensitization program for journalists, informing the public via the news media, and training for frontline forest guards, rangers, and foresters. Project activities will include: 1) conduct two workshops for frontline forest staff covering topics such as HEC-mitigation methods and human-elephant coexistence; 2) conduct a workshop for journalists and reporters in order to cultivate an informed media community that will report objectively and constructively on HEC issues and highlight HEC-mitigation measures; and 3) conduct follow-up assessments with workshop participants three months post-training to measure uptake and application of workshop content. This project will encourage attitudinal change towards elephants in HEC-affected areas and will help to conserve the species in the long-term and facilitate harmonious co-existence.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Strengthening communities to reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) and deforestation through community livelihood improvement training, cooking gas benefits, and conservation education in HEC-sensitive Shyampur village, Uttarakhand, India

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to make poor, human-elephant conflict (HEC) affected and forest-dependent womens groups self-reliant in income generation and to link that livelihood improvement with habitat and wildlife conservation in order to reduce HEC and deforestation in and around these fringe communities of the Hardwar Forest Division, Uttarakhand. Project activities will include: 1) conduct meetings with HEC-affected villages and frontline forest staff in order to assess HEC intensity; 2) construction of a Community Livelihood Improvement (CLI) training center; 3) initiation of HEC mitigation and habitat protection-linked cooking gas subsidy for 50+ HEC-affected families (to reduce dependence on fuel wood harvest); 4) conduct two train-the-trainer workshops for village leaders and teachers; 5) to provide anti-poaching training to a subset of community members in order to form a Community Anti-poaching Squad; 6) conduct two joint HEC workshops involving both womens groups and local Forest Department staff; and 7) develop HEC mitigation and habitat protection outreach and resource materials for the CLI center. This project will incentivize villager participation in HEC mitigation habitat protection schemes by providing economic motivators and livelihood improvement training to HEC-affected communities...This award period of performance will be one year; however the project is expected to extend over a two-year period. Pending receipt of financial and performance reports and availability of funds, the award may be extended for an additional year and the balance of the total request in the amount of $23,230.50 will be obligated at that time."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conflict to coexistence: enhancing community-managed conservation of Asian elephants in Golaghat, Assam, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to assist the Forest Department in the conservation of Asian elephants in the Golaghat District of Assam by assisting the Forest Department in the planning and establishment of a Conservation Reserve. Project activities will include: 1) conducting land use surveys in the corridors, formation and capacity building of local stakeholder committees, and installing outreach billboards; 2) assessing human-elephant conflict (HEC), collecting and mapping HEC data on riverine islands in the region; 3) conducting an awareness campaign on the riverine islands; 4) forming local womens weaving Self Help Groups for alternative income generation and conducting a week-long microenterprise development training workshop on the riverine islands; 6) conducting awareness meetings, teachers trainings, and a three-day nature orientation initiative for local youths; 7) training on beekeeping and fishery management for local youths; 8) training of local farmers on the cultivation of elephant-repelling crops such as citrus and chili peppers; 9) equipping anti-depredation squads; and 10) collecting data via surveys for micro-planning exercises. This project will support the Assam Forest Department in their efforts to create a Conservation Reserve in the Golaghat district which will serve to protect and conserve the populations and habitats of the Asian elephant in the region.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Population estimate and trans-boundary collaboration for Asian elephant in Manas National Park, Assam, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to collect and update Asian elephant population data in Manas National Park, Assam, in order to better manage and protect the species and landscape. Project activities will include: 1) estimation of elephant population status, size, structure, and distributions in the Park; 2) assessment of habitat use patterns; 3) establishment of transboundary Bhutan-India collaborations, including workshops and trainings; and 4) conduct outreach via posters and billboards to local Park stakeholders. This project will enhance transboundary collaboration on elephant conservation and population monitoring between Bhutanese authorities in Royal Manas National Park and Indias Manas National Park.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Community-based management of human-elephant conflict in the northern Western Ghats, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to extend the Community-Based Conflict Management model previously implemented by the recipient in North Karnara, Maharashtra into the districts of Belgaum and Southern Maharashtra, India in order to reduce negative interactions between farmers and Asian elephants in those districts. Project activities will include: 1) capacity building of farmers in community-based management of human-elephant conflict (HEC); 2) prepare a detailed manual on low cost crop protection methods used in Asia and Africa; 3) create a database of wild elephants using photographic identification; 4) real time monitoring of elephant locations using the Western Ghats portal and an online spatial data entry format, in partnership with the Forest Department; 5) produce an awareness film; and 6) extension activities and handicraft production capacity development in local communities. This project will contribute to securing the future of Asian elephants in the northern Western Ghats landscape and increase empathy and tolerance among local communities for conservation of elephants.

title.narrative: Evaluation of the present status of the elephant corridors of Assam, India and preparation of an Action Plan for their conservation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the status of the nine designated Asian elephant corridors of Assam and prioritize activities for their long-term conservation. Project activities will be carried out by the Assam Forest Department and will include: 1) evaluation of the nine elephant corridors of Assam using official records and conducting household surveys of residents of the corridors; 2) corridor mapping, including vegetation cover, villages, land use patterns, and elephant routes; and 3) preparation of an action plan for the conservation of the corridors and recommendations for securing and management of the corridors. This project will contribute to the long-term conservation of viable populations of Asian elephants in Assam, the optimization of the use and conservation of existing habitats, and mitigation of human-elephant conflict.

title.narrative: Anti-poaching and anti-depredation camps for conservation of Asian elephants in Kaziranga National Park, Assam, India

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to support the Forest Department of Assam in their efforts to conserve and protect Asian elephants and their habitats in Kaziranga National Park. This award will provide funding for the construction of three anti-poaching camps in the Park, these permanent camps will provide furnished lodging for frontline field staff and include running water and watchtowers. Construction of these anti-poaching outposts in the Park will improve the living conditions of frontline rangers and patrol staff of Kaziranga which will improve the protection of elephants, Indian rhinos, and other endangered species therein. ..This award period of performance will be one year; however the project is expected to extend over a two-year period. Pending receipt of financial and performance reports and availability of funds, the award may be extended for an additional year and the balance of the total request in the amount of $59,190.00 will be obligated at that time."

title.narrative: Providing support for a regional Asian elephant and tiger veterinary workshop

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide theoretical and practical training for range state practicing veterinarians in veterinary interventions for the conservation of Asian elephants and tigers in their range countries. The recipient will host a Regional Asian Elephant and Tiger Veterinary Workshop in 2015, in collaboration with the Department of Forest and Wildlife, Government of Kerala, in Pookode, Kerala, India. The Workshop will address wildlife health from an ecosystem perspective and discuss such topics as veterinary practices in elephants and tigers (e.g., health checks, preventative medicine, nutrition, husbandry, diagnosis and treatment of disease, routine medical procedures); chemical immobilization (e.g., risk assessment, procedure, identification of drugs and supplies); disease surveillance (e.g., sample collection, laboratory techniques, conducting post-mortems, data collection, assessment of habitat health and stresses); veterinary aspects of human-wildlife conflict; and veterinary field research for elephant and tiger conservation. The Workshop will also provide hands-on opportunities for learning, including field visits to elephant camps and to the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve and Wayanaud Wildlife Sanctuary. The recipient will identify and invite 25 veterinarians from Asian elephant and tiger range states, and provide support for their travel to and participation in the Workshop. Following the Workshop, the recipient will continue support for information-sharing and networking among participants, promoting collaborations and knowledge exchanges both regionally and internationally. This project will ultimately lead to an overall increase of regional veterinary understanding of ecosystem health and medical management of Asian elephants and tigers.

title.narrative: Strengthening communities to reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) and deforestation through community livelihood improvement training, cooking gas benefits, and conservation education in HEC-sensitive Shyampur village, Hardwar Forest Division, Uttarakhand, India

description.narrative: This award period of performance will be one year; however the project is expected to extend over a two-year period. Pending receipt of financial and performance reports and availability of funds, the award may be extended for an additional year and the balance of the total request in the amount of $23,230.50 will be obligated at that time. Despite being reviewed and ranked a top tier proposal, due to budget constraints, this project was funded at 60% the requested amount ($45,094.50 rather than $68,325.00) due to the high budget request and the number of excellent proposals that were given high scores. The applicant was asked to spread the work and the budget over two years with the funds obligated over two fiscal years. Had sufficient funds been available, the proposal would have been funded fully in FY15, the award was made with the understanding that pending availability of funds and receipt of financial and performance reports the award would be extended and the balance of funds obligated if they become available. Augmenting this award allows the recipient to complete the full scope of work outlined in the original proposal and on the original timeline.

title.narrative: Community-based management of human-elephant conflict in the North Kanara Landscape and transfer of Community-Based Conflict Management Technology to Forest Departments of other states in India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to contribute to the conservation of wild Asian elephants in North Karnara, Karnataka, India by increasing the tolerance towards elephants via Community Based Conflict Management (CBCM), disseminate these techniques to other states of India, and influence wild elephant management policy at the national level. Specific activities will include: 1) capacity building in CBCM techniques, apiculture and bee hive fences; 2) training on local elephant-themed- handicrafts and elephant dung paper production; 3) educational film on elephant behavior and sociality produced and screened for local communities; 4) real-time internet-based monitoring of elephants in collaboration with the Karnataka Forest Department; and 5) transfer of CBCM techniques to Forest Departments of other state and influencing elephant management policies through workshops.

title.narrative: Augment the capacity of the Sundarban Biosphere Reserve Directorate to enhance tiger habitat management and address human-tiger conflict

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to augment the capacity of the Sundarbans Biosphere Reserve directorate for enhanced tiger conservation and develop long-term, sustainable management measures to address human-tiger conflict. The objectives are as follows: (1) Conduct a robust prey-base study in three ranges of 24-Parganas and provide this information to Park managers to facilitate monitoring of tigers and protected areas in the Sundarbans, and (2) Reduce tiger straying incidences into villages and human-tiger conflicts within the protected area.

title.narrative: Strengthen the protection measures in Manas National Park as a part of the program Indian Rhino Vision 2020 to expand the numbers and range of wild rhinos in Assam, Phase-X

description.narrative: In partnership with Wildlife Areas Development and Welfare Trust. The purpose of this project is to reduce levels of threat to Indian rhinoceros and other wildlife, improve security, and enhance patrolling to control illegal activities through focused and practical actions in and around Manas National Park (MNP), where rhinoceroses have been reintroduced. The project will support the salary of an additional 15 guards for 12 months, to keep vigil and monitor the rhinos in MNP. Preference for hiring of guards will be given to persons from the areas adjoining the park to improve their socioeconomic status, and help develop a good relationship between the Park management and the fringe villagers. The Forest Department will train the newly recruited guards on wildlife conservation and methods to combat poaching.

title.narrative: Strengthen the protection measures in Laokhowa & Burachapori Wildlife Sanctuaries as a part of the program Indian Rhino Vision 2020 to expand the numbers and range of wild rhinos in Assam

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce levels of threat to Indian rhinoceros and other wildlife, improve security, and enhance patrolling to control illegal activities through focused and practical actions in and around the national park and sanctuaries. Rhinoceroses are currently being reintroduced to these sanctuaries. The project will support, (1) the construction of 4 anti-poaching watch towers, (2) purchase of one 4x4 vehicle for patrolling, (3) purchase of a motor boat, (4) construction of one floating patrol camp, and (5) training of around 30 frontline Forest Department staff, on modern methods to combat poaching, on the importance of communication network and how to use them, on how to establish intelligence network with the local villagers, on usage of patrol forms and record keeping, on reporting schedule and format, on wildlife conservation in general and rhino conservation in particular, on camp behavior, and Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrolling.

title.narrative: Building support for Tiger Conservation in Karbi-Anglong, Assam, India through capacity building, community engagement and outreach education

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect tigers and their prey base in Karbi Anglong district adjacent to Kaziranga National Park. The project will, (1) Enhance the protection of reserve forests (RFs) and protected areas of East Karbi Anglong Forest Division adjacent to KNP by engaging around 20 community volunteers in tiger/rhino protection during seasonal floods, and equipping around 40 front line forest staff with basic field gear, including uniforms, flashlights, shoes, leech guard, rain gear, mosquito nets, sleeping bags, backpacks, battery supplies, GPS units, binoculars, digital cameras, compass, and search lights to improve their efficiency for the protection of tigers and habitat, and improve morale; (2) Orient and train around 40 front line forest staff with basic wildlife monitoring/patrol techniques and reporting skills; and (3) Mobilize community based tiger conservation education awareness campaigns and outreach activities for a wider section of nearby communities, leaders , teachers, student, and general public.

title.narrative: Development of Forensic DNA Analysis Support System for Greater One-horned Rhino in Assam and West Bengal

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the law implementing authorities in Assam and West Bengal in developing a DNA database of rhinos to aid in forensic investigations of rhino crime cases. The project will, (1) Develop the forensic DNA database of rhinos from the protected areas of Assam and Northern West Bengal; (2) Train Forest Department field officers on DNA forensic protocols including crime scene handling and sample collection, etc., and develop and distribute low-cost forensic sampling kits; and (3) Assist forensic investigations through linking confiscated biological material with the scene of crime and assigning to a source population, by providing on the ground support for forensic sample handling and collection, and aiding in crime scene investigations through expedited DNA analysis support.

title.narrative: Developing a human-big cats conflict mitigation model for the benefit of the local communities and at the same time survival of big cats in Assam, India, Phase-II

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build positive attitudes towards big cat conservation with emphasis on tiger conservation and to reduce the conflict by minimizing loss of big cats and human lives. The project will, (1) Develop awareness programs and involve people and local administration in mitigating conflict; (2) Maintain support for Rapid Response Teams with capture and transport equipment; (3) Maintain local response teams to respond to tiger and leopard encounters; and (4) Continue training Forest Department staff and local administrators and members of the Rapid Response Teams and Primary Response Teams. Rapid Response Teams (RRT) and Primary Response Teams (PRT) formed with grant support will tackle human-tiger and human-leopard conflict situations. The grant will contribute to the salaries of the 15 trained forest staff, 3 veterinarians, support necessary training, and purchase of essential supplies.

title.narrative: Strengthen the protection measures in Kaziranga and Manas National Park through advanced patrolling as a part of the program Indian Rhino Vision 2020 Phase-II

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to help better manage the Protected Areas of Assam. Project objectives are as follows: (1) Establish best practice systems that can improve the effective use of information for conservation and monitoring; (2) The development and use of standardized processes together with flexibility to meet the different needs of the protected areas guidelines for data collection, analysis, and presentation that will promote meaningful assessment and enable comparability of conservation data across information management systems; (3) Develop suitable forms of spatial monitoring and recording tools to meet the management needs of protected area of Assam; and (4) Improve security in Kaziranga NP and Manas NP through improvised patrolling and monitoring, and continue support to run the existing Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrolling in both the parks.

title.narrative: Assisting Conservation and protection of tigers and habitats in the upper Brahmaputra Valleys of Assam and Arunachal Pradesh, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to understand tiger conservation potential of core tiger habitats and their connectivity corridors to ensure long term conservation of tigers. The project objectives are as follows: (1) Estimate abundance and distribution of tigers, co-predators and prey animals in Dibru-Saikhowa National Park (DSNP) and adjoining forest areas, by systematic camera trapping in 340 sq km area of the park; (2) Evaluate habitats and connectivity corridors within DSNP and surrounding areas, by conducting baseline field studies and ground truth verification of habitats to prepare a temporal Land Use Land Cover database, by mapping the connectivity corridors in the area using Remote Sensing - Geographical Information System tools; (3) Evaluate threats to tigers, co-predators, habitats and prey animals in the park, adjoining forests and on the connectivity corridors, and review present conservation efforts of the core tiger habitats and connectivity corridors in the area, prepare a spatial database of threats on the habitats and corridors, and prepare a draft conservation action plan for the conservation of tiger habitats and connectivity corridors.

title.narrative: Healthcare program for the wellibeing of Asian elephants engaged in the protection of the wildlife areas of Assam, India, Phase-II

description.narrative: This project will provide free healthcare to the captive elephants engaged in the protection of the protected areas of Assam, India and will ensure their well-being and check the spread of communicable diseases to their wild counterparts. Periodic Healthcare and Vaccination Camps will be held to conduct routine check-ups including blood, urine, stool analysis and prevention and control of parasites; an on-call veterinarian will make visits for emergencies and elephants that need special attention for acute illness. Follow-up visits will be arranged. Health charts for each elephant will be maintained. Funds will go to building the capacity of mahouts to provide better preventative care to their elephants. Young veterinarians from the region will receive training in elephant healthcare and will be engaged during the Camps; and a network involving veterinarians trained in elephant healthcare will be created so that more timely care can be provided to acute cases. This project will contribute to the conservation of wild Asian elephants in Northeast India, which is home to 15% of the world population this species.

title.narrative: Safe guarding the Greater One-horned Rhino meta-population in North Bengal and Uttar Pradesh, India with community support through conservation education and awareness

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring about attitudinal and behavior change among people living near protected areas with small rhino populations and to coexist with the animals. The objectives are as follows: (1) To educate educators and community members about the importance of rhinos and its conservation; (2) To reduce human-rhino conflict by conveying positive attitudes and effective preventative and practical behavior; (3) To evaluate participants to ascertain the extent to which they used the information and material given in the primary workshop and find out about the problems they encountered; (4) To create a network of educators that can help promote species conservation beyond project period.

title.narrative: Conservation Education and Capacity Building for Tiger Conservation in the Protected Areas of Arunachal Pradesh

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to create awareness about tiger conservation through education and training, and build the capacity and strengthen the management skills of forest front-line staff. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Train the trainers: train educators to promote tiger conservation in Arunachal Pradesh, by conducting a three-day teacher training workshop for educators, forest personnel, NGOs and interested individuals; (2) At a 5-day capacity building/training workshop, provide up to date information on wildlife conservation and management. The workshops should train more than 40 people who will subsequently train others.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Training on Habitat Management and Wildlife Conservation for the front line forest personnel of the Protected Areas of Assam, India Phase-V.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to train field level staff (1) in wildlife conservation so they can better understand their role in conservation and they can play a more useful role in implementing wildlife and habitat management programs, (2) on better patrolling techniques including SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) programs for all the National Parks in Assam and Lawkhowa Burachapori WLS (excluding Kaziranga and Manas, where training has already been completed on SMART), and (3) on how to mitigate human-animal conflict in all the National Parks and Tigers Reserves of Assam.

title.narrative: Forest Department - Community partnership to improve protection of western Hoolock Gibbons Hoolock hoolock in Jeypore RF, Phase-IV

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to establish a long-term protection mechanism and serve as a model for enhancing protection of critical wildlife sites in NE India where situations are dire and manpower is short. The project will accomplish the following objectives and associated activities: (1) Continue the operations of the two roving gibbon and wildlife patrol units comprising of 3 community members and headed by a forest guard. A new group will also be introduced this year resulting in a total of 3 groups. (2) Implement SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrolling protocols; systematically record patrol details and produce monthly reports; plan future patrols using these reports. FWS support will provide the salaries of 8 guards and honorariums for 3 forest staff for 12 months. There will be special training of the guards on wildlife conservation, how to combat poaching, and SMART patrolling.

title.narrative: Strengthening Tiger Conservation Capacity of Karnataka Forest Department.Staff through Focused Training

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to increase the tiger population in Karnataka through improved technical capacity of the Forest Department to protect and monitor tigers. The project objectives are to, (1) train frontline Forest Department staff on protection techniques and monitoring methodologies, (2) facilitate science-based, and directed conservation practices by park managers, and (3) include current concepts and techniques of wildlife conservation in the curricula of key forestry colleges. Training will be field based as well as in class rooms at forestry institutes.

title.narrative: Building local capacity for conserving a recovering tiger population in the newly declared Amrabad Tiger Reserve, Telangana, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to assist in the recovery of tiger numbers in the Eastern Ghats landscape, centered around the Amrabad Tiger Reserve (ATR), Nagarjunasagar Srisailam Tiger Reserve (NSTR) forest complex, such that these forests hold a thriving and viable tiger metapopulation. The project objectives are to rigorously document threats to tiger population recovery in terms of current prey base and human disturbance, build local capacity for tiger conservation and monitoring, and collaborate with the government in using data on tiger numbers and threat incidence to improve tiger conservation efforts.

title.narrative: Conservation of the tiger in buffer zone of Melghat Tiger Reserve

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conserve tigers in the buffer zone outside the protected area. The project objectives are as follows: (1) Monitor tigers in the project area by camera trap sampling, provide these results to the Forest Department, and support the Forest Department in line transect monitoring for prey species; (2) Strengthen wildlife protection, prevention of wildlife crime and improved law enforcement by building the capacity of Forest Department field staff with the assistance of expert trainers; (3) Reduce the pressures on forests for firewood and fodder, prevent and control forest fires, implement sustainable utilization practices and address community issues related to wildlife conservation, initiate a dialogue with the community to control livestock grazing on forest land and implement sustainable forest management practices, and mitigate human-wildlife conflict; and (4) Develop livelihood options for the local community, such as providing market links for bamboo products, and other non-timber forest products (NTFP) that utilize the forest in sustainable ways as opposed to overexploitation.

title.narrative: Recovering tigers at the confluence of Western and Eastern Ghats in southern India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to enable the recovery of the tiger, its prey and their habitat in the Malai Mahadeshwara Wildlife Sanctuary (MM Hills) Cauvery Wildlife Sanctuary (CWS) landscape by assisting park managements in reducing conservation threats and leveraging conservation opportunities by using approaches that are grounded in an understanding of both ecology and society. The project objectives are as follows: (1) To work with Karnataka Forest Department to improve capacity for wildlife protection and management of frontline staff of the recently gazetted/expanded protected areas; (2) To strengthen habitat connectivity between MM Hills and CWS and by working with government agencies to implement mitigation measures to reduce impacts of a highway, increase driver awareness through public outreach, use camera traps to assess wildlife use of D-E corridor, complete surveys of vehicular traffic volume on the Hasanur Ghat road to understand usage of this corridor on the highway passing through the corridor, by designing, developing and undertaking a wildlife collision prevention program through driver awareness programs, education material, billboards, handouts, etc., and based on study results develop suitable mitigation plans and initiate discussions with various government agencies to explore possibilities of implementing mitigation measures; (3) To undertake outreach activities around the parks to improve support of local communities, social leaders and opinion builders for wildlife conservation in the landscape; (4) To assess and evaluate conservation impacts of the above interventions by monitoring tigers and their prey, and livestock. FWS support is primarily for camera traps, motorcycles to improve the mobility of Forest Department patrol staff, and awareness billboards.

title.narrative: Strengthening communities in human-tiger conflict (HTC) sensitive Dhela forest range of the Corbett Tiger Reserve, India through income generating development skill training, alternative cooking fuel

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to strengthen the capacity of the local villagers around the Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR) through community livelihood improvement and income generating skill development training program, and help them develop positive understanding and appreciation for wildlife, and coordinate with the Forest Department to reduce human tiger/wildlife conflicts and deforestation. The project objectives are as follows: (1) Build a Community Livelihood Improvement (CLI) Training Center (CLITC) for the human-tiger conflict (HTC) affected womens communities in Dhela forest range of the CTR; (2) Provide income generating skill development training in the CLITC to the forest-dependent women stakeholders of Dhela forest range; (3) Provide alternative cooking fuel and cooking gas subsidy to the human-tiger conflict affected families in the Dhela forest range; (4) Build the capacity of the frontline forest staff working at the forest check posts in Dhela forest range; (5) Initiate developing a Community Plant Nursery as a measure to promote community-led tiger habitat protection in Dhela forest range; (6) Propagate HTC mitigation awareness education campaign in the HTC sensitive villages around the CTR.

title.narrative: Database on Tiger Poaching and Trade and Related Wildlife Crimes in India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain a database on tiger poaching, trade, and related wildlife crimes, which helps enforcement officers to monitor and control wildlife crime and illegal wildlife trafficking in the Indian Subcontinent. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Collect and update data on wildlife crime in India particularly related to wild tigers the Indian rhinoceros, Asian elephant, leopard, otter, pangolin and other endangered species listed in Indias Wild Life (Protection) Act; (2) Understand the changing modus operandi of wildlife criminals and trafficking routes; (3) Assist enforcement agencies in detecting wildlife crimes and the effective prosecution of wildlife criminals; and (4) Disseminate information on wildlife crime, and strengthen policy issues and the implementation of wildlife legislation.

title.narrative: Rhino range expansion in the state of Utta Pradesh, Terai Arc landscape, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to rebuild rhino populations in potential areas within the state of Uttar Pradesh (UP) and secure them in new habitats, minimizing the risk of genetic imbalances and stochastic events, and expand the population to new areas providing the chance for the species to have a more secure future. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Assess the rhino ranging patterns and habitat preference of rhinos within Dudhwa National Park (DNP) and Manas National Park (MNP) to set standards for identifying potential habitat; (2) Identify and map potential rhino habitats in TAL of Uttar Pradesh for future re-introduction of rhinos; (3) Understand the genetic make-up of the existing rhino population in DNP; and (4) Assist the Forest Department in establishing a second rhino population within DNP.

title.narrative: Rhino Translocation from Chitwan National Park to Suklaphanta Wildlife Reserve, Nepal

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the survival of the greater one-horned rhinoceros in Nepal by creating a second viable subpopulation in western Terai Arc Landscape, Nepal. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Prepare for the translocation of rhinos from Chitwan National Park (CNP) to Shuklaphanta Wildlife Reserve (SWR); and (2) Capture and translocate rhinos to SWR.

title.narrative: Forest Guard Training for Conservation of Hoolock gibbon in the state of Arunachal Pradesh, India

description.narrative: The project will accomplish the following objectives to help conserve endangered western hoolock gibbons and their habitats in Arunachal Pradesh: (1) Educate, and inculcate interest in Forest Guards to protect hoolock gibbon habitats, and educate them about global, national and local importance of the species; (2) Train Forest Guards to identify the different primate species, and classify individuals based on age and sex to facilitate individual identification to maintain individual histories; (3) Teach and train the Forest Guards about general primate survey, hoolock gibbon population estimates and the present status of Hoolock gibbons; (4) Train them about legal provisions in the Wildlife Act as well as wildlife laws to reduce wildlife crimes; (5) Sensitize field staff about the value and ethics of wildlife conservation and bio-diversity propagation by bringing about an attitudinal change among forest staff and the local community.

title.narrative: Capacity building in assessing impact of linear infrastructure development and.developing mitigation measures in tiger (Panthera tigris) range countries in Asia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to organize and conduct a training workshop for professionals from 3 tiger range countries at a suitable location in India. This train the trainers workshop is intended to help develop much needed capacity among tiger/wildlife biologists to understand and address the impacts of linear infrastructure projects, so that they can be better prepared to address this new, very serious emerging threat to the long-term demographic viability of tiger populations. Trainees will be selected from Bhutan, India, and Nepal. Expert road ecologists from the U.S.A. (USG and partners) will provide the training.

title.narrative: Expand Community Based Sea Turtle Conservation Program and Integrate Related Enforcement Departments for Better Advocacy in Andhra Pradesh and Odisha, India.

description.narrative: The recipient will continue a community based sea turtle nest protection program along 170 km of nesting beaches on the Bay of Bengal, involving 60 villages and conduct outreach programs with fishers to reduce sea turtle bycatch through use of TEDs and offshore patrolling. The recipient will engage artisanal fishers through interactive sessions to coordinate with policy makers on sea turtle conservation issues.

title.narrative: Augment the capacity of the West Bengal Forest Directorate to address human-elephant conflict in SW West Bengal, India.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) and support the conservation of Asian elephants in West Bengal, India. WWF-India in collaboration with forestry authorities of West Bengal will work to understand the context for HEC in in southwest West Bengal and augment the capacity of the forest authorities to manage elephant conservation. Broad project objectives are: 1) facilitate strategic decision-making among the three divisions in southwest West Bengal with detailed information on landscape-level elephant movement and barriers to that movement; 2) implement best practices to minimize HEC through community participation; and 3) conduct awareness campaigns and exposure visits to reduce HEC and increase appreciation for elephants at a local level. Project activities include: 1) identification of causal factors of HEC; 2) documentation and mapping of villages and physical barriers; 3) development of landscape-level barrier strategy and maintenance plan; 4) stakeholder analysis to understand knowledge, attitudes, and practices in ten priority communities; 5) development model villages; 6) establish and train three voluntary HEC response units of 15 skilled individuals each; 6) conduct education campaigns including meetings, film screenings, street plays, posters, and road signs; and 7) exposure visits for frontline staff, mahouts, response unit members to an established site in Assam. The project will contribute to the conservation of wild Asian elephants in West Bengal, India by working with the forest authorities to address HEC in the region via sustainable management measures.

title.narrative: Strengthening protection machinery for Asian elephant conservation through research and community edge in Dehing Patkai Elephant Reerve, Assam.

description.narrative: This project continues the work undertaken in USFWS award F14AP00258, focusing on wild Asian elephant conservation in the Dehing Patkai Elephant Reserve of Assam, India, a transboundary landscape and a hotspot of human-elephant conflict (HEC). This project will continue to collect dung DNA samples for elephant population estimates and assist the Forest Department in gazetting the landscape as a national park. Project activities include: 1) estimation of the elephant population in the Reserve via dung count methods; 2) surveys of local communities to determine their dependency on elephant corridors; 3) construction of elephant conservation sign boards in the corridor; 4) training of at least 200 frontline Forest Department staff on GPS-based elephant monitoring, including a study tour to Kaziranga National Park; 5) provision of field gear including shoes and rain gear to 200 field staff; 6) awareness programs on human-elephant coexistence to local communities and schools, including teacher trainings; 7) training of ecotourism livelihood diversification for 50 local youths; 8) cultivation of unpalatable crops such as citrus and king chilies; 9) support of local bilateral meetings between Assam and Arunachal Pradesh Forest Departments to improve inter-state cooperation on elephant conservation; and 10) initiate dialogue with Myanmar wildlife authorities and Assam and Arunachal Pradesh Forest Departments to propose the idea of transboundary elephant conservation collaborations. This project will contribute to the long-term protection and survival of Asian elephants and their habitats in Assam via research, capacity building of Forest Department staff, mitigation of HEC and continual involvement of local communities.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation of Asian elephant in the riverine areas of Diblugarh, Sibsagar and Jorhat districts of Eastern Assam.

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to conserve wild Asian elephants by addressing human-elephant conflict (HEC) in the riverine areas along the Brahmaputra River in Dibrugarh, Sibsagar, and Jorhat Districts of eastern Assam, India in collaboration with local communities. The major objectives of this project are to investigate the abundance and distribution patterns of elephants in this region, assess the extent of HEC, test low-cost HEC mitigation techniques, and conduct capacity building exercises for both the local community and Forest Department staff. Project activities include: 1) single season presence-absence survey of elephants using line transects; 2) data collection on HEC events including crop raiding, property damage, and human and elephant injury and death; 3) mapping of HEC zones using GIS tools; 4) cultivation of alternative unpalatable crops such as lemon and lemongrass; 5) cultivation of elephant forage species in communal village land including the development of a nursery with the capacity to raise 80,000 seedlings; 6) testing of HEC mitigation approaches such as lights and firecrackers; 7) provision of gear to Forest Department anti-depredation squads including boots, jackets, rain gear, and first aid kits; and 8) awareness programs targeting local communities and schools. This project will contribute to the conservation of Asian elephants in the eastern region of Assam by increasing our understanding of elephant usage of the landscape, mitigation of HEC, and increasing the local communitys understanding of elephant conservation issues. ."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Securing the globally critical Asian elephant population in Nagarahole-Bandipur National Parks, India, through habitat consolidation and threat mitigation.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to ensure that the wild Asian elephant metapopulation in the Mysore Elephant Reserve (MER) is healthy and free of pressures that threaten its persistence in the Western Ghats, India. Securing key source populations of elephants and consolidation of habitat is critical to protecting this population and will be addressed via support of voluntary resettlement of within-forest villages and intelligence gathering on wildlife crimes. Project activities include: 1) confidence-building measures to motivate families to relocate outside of the MER, increasing political and public support for voluntary resettlement; 2) provision of support to families who wish to relocate including liaising with appropriate government departments; 3) carry out land-use classification of the MER using GIS tools and ground-truthing to prioritize sites for strategic land purchase; and 4) gather and verify information using an intelligence network to minimize threats to elephants and their habitats. The project will directly contribute to securing habitat within MER through reduction of human-elephant conflict and minimize threats from illegal activities such as ivory poaching and timber smuggling in the Western Ghats of India.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Mitigating humanelephant conflict to strengthen a network of elephant-friendly tea plantations in a critical elephant landscape in Northeast India.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to have a thriving population of wild Asian elephants in a low-threat environment within the Kaziranga-Karbi Anglong Elephant Reserve of Assam, India. Project objectives will address concerns for human safety resulting from elephants use of tea plantations, while simultaneously enhancing support for elephant conservation through implementation of human-elephant conflict (HEC) mitigation activities, individual elephant identification system, and outreach and education campaigns. Project activities include 1) stakeholder meetings with tea plantation staff to develop and initiate early warning systems and other HEC mitigation strategies; 2) training locals to identify elephants and in data collection; 3) tailor HEC mitigations to the specific behaviors of individual elephants in collaboration with plantation staff; and 4) cultivate positive attitudes of local people towards elephant conservation through awareness activities. This project will strengthen the network of elephant-friendly tea plantations in Assam, such that these plantations can serve as secondary habitat, movement corridors, refuge for elephants during floods, and expand support for elephant conservation in the Reserve.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: The Odisha Elephant Landscape Project.

description.narrative: The Odisha Elephant Landscape Project aims to protect wild Asian elephants and their habitats and mitigate human-elephant conflict (HEC) and intentional killings in Odisha, India by supporting the Odisha Forest Department through elephant monitoring, creation of threat maps, identifying open wells, monitoring poachers, and facilitating crop compensation claims after HEC events. Project activities include: 1) support for local forest protection groups to prevent poaching, reduce HEC, and raise awareness among local communities and school children; 2) monitor and provide information to the Forest Department about poacher movements, threats to elephants such as illegal development, open wells, low power lines, electric traps, and illegal or defunct electric fences; 3) monitor known elephant corridors for illegal activities such as mining, quarrying, dumping, and pollution; 4) provide recommendations to the forest authorities on habitat protection and HEC compensation methods using satellite mapping; 5) facilitate crop damage claims for farmers from the Forest Department; 6) ensure effective forest fire response by the Forest Department by monitoring and reporting fires quickly; 7) create pilot nurseries of bauhinia vines for use as alternative livelihood and elephant fodder plants; and 8) inform the media to generate positive news stories in support of elephant conservation and to highlight threats. This multifaceted project will support the Forest Department in reducing threats to Asian elephants, enrich elephant habitat, support alternative livelihoods in Odisha, and increase awareness and understanding in local communities and media.

description.narrative: Melghat Tiger Reserve is an important source population of the tiger and supports a population of 50 tigers. It is connected by a forest corridor to Satpuda Tiger Reserve. The presence of tiger and prey species and the status of this corridor is not well studied. The buffer zone of Melghat tiger reserve has presence of tiger and prey species but is not being monitored for tigers by the Forest Department. Project objectives are to: (1) carry out an occupancy survey for tigers and prey in the corridor connecting Melghat Tiger Reserve with Satpuda tiger Reserve, and, (2) deploy camera traps for estimating minimum tiger population and tiger distribution in buffer zone of Melghat Tiger Reserve.

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE ENDANGERED WESTERN HOOLOCK GIBBON IN COMMUNITY-MANAGED FORESTS OF NORTHEAST INDIA

description.narrative: The endangered western hoolock gibbon (Hoolock hoolock) is threatened by loss of closed-canopy forests, and illegal hunting. In the hill states of Northeast India, the closed-canopy forests that gibbons inhabit is largely under the ownership and management of communities. While there is local conservation interest to secure forests and gibbons, these local initiatives are in need of outside support, largely to address two main threats to gibbons. The first is changing land-use patterns and erosion of traditional practices of conserving village forests are resulting in loss of the species habitat, while the second is that gibbons are being directly impacted by illegal hunting. Project objectives include to: (1) implement conservation initiatives to reduce threats to the western hoolock gibbon in select community-managed forests of Nagaland and Meghalaya; (2) assess the potential for gibbon conservation in community-managed forests of Khasi Hills and Ri-Bhoi districts, Meghalaya; and, (3) spread awareness of gibbons as a flagship species for closed-canopy forests in Northeast India.

title.narrative: MONITORING OF KEY TIGER (PANTHERA TIGRIS TIGRIS) POPULATIONS IN CORRIDORS IN CENTRAL INDIAN TIGER LANDSCAPE, INDIA

description.narrative: Recent scientific work on tigers shows that to ensure long-term viable tiger populations it is essential to focus on corridors connecting tiger source sites. A landscape-level approach towards maintaining meta-populations is key, but in a developing economy like India which supports about 60% of the global tiger population, conserving multiple use areas (corridors) is very challenging. The burgeoning infrastructural expansion, linear structures and projects such as mining seriously threaten the persistence of these corridors and strongly impact wildlife. The goal of the project is to upgrade the status of key tiger bearing areas outside Protected Areas (PAs), ensuring better wildlife management strategies and mainstreaming of such areas into tiger conservation strategies. Project objectives include: (1) To generate long-term spatial data on tiger densities and population dynamics of tigers outside PAs to influence the larger tiger conservation policy framework at the landscape and national level; and, (2) To build the capacity of forest staff and other stakeholders in monitoring tiger populations outside PAs and use of individual-level data in human-tiger conflict mitigation, planning mitigation measures for linear infrastructures, monitor dispersal events, etc.
