title.narrative: Conservation of Tiger, Rhino, Elephants and Hoolock Gibbons in Kaziranga-Karb Anglong Landscape using PNRM Approach by Forest Dependent Indigenous Karbi Tribe in Kohora River Basin in India

description.narrative: It is the necessary to ensure alternative mode of protection to habitats in Karbi Anglong Hills and the biological corridors to Kaziranga National Park as the indigenous Karbi tribe is not in favor of the creation of a Wildlife Sanctuary fearing loss of land rights and natural resources. Project will engage communities using traditional knowledge and appropriate technology to design sustainable and adaptive Participatory Natural Resources Management (PNRM) models for habitat conservation and reduce human disturbances. Beneficiaries will be trained for improved homestead agroforestry, sustainable harvest of Non Timber Forest Products (NTFP), value addition and marketing of products. Project objectives are: (1) Inventory and mapping of NTFP in the River Basin that are potential for sustainable management and creating a baseline; (2) Participatory perspective plan for Natural Resource Management; (3) Develop natural resource based sustainable livelihood and entrepreneurship models involving 100 households to initiate habitat protection and improved quality of life; (4) Document the process and system of best practices for communication with wider communities and stakeholders; and, (5) Create awareness among communities and stakeholders about ecosystems health, PNRM, livelihoods and entrepreneurships.

title.narrative: Facilitating expansion of the network of tiger source populations within the Malenad Tiger Landscape

description.narrative: The Malenad Tiger Landscape (MTL) supports a large tiger population, and the Wildlife Conservation Society India Program has been working to conserve, monitor and study tigers, their prey and habitat in key sites within the MTL for over three decades. Recognizing that source-sink dynamics are important in determining the spatial distribution of tigers across large landscapes, such a site-based approach to conservation focuses on source sites with concentrations of tigers that have the potential to repopulate the larger landscape of sinks, which in turn need to be managed to facilitate movement of tigers and prey, but not necessarily to support high densities throughout. Project objectives are to: (1) Facilitate government-sponsored voluntary, relocation of forest-interior families to new sites outside the forest; (2) Prevent, detect and control threats to wildlife and habitats through an active intelligence network in the new sites; and, (3) Assess and map the emergent threat of minor forest produce collection.

title.narrative: Facilitating tiger population recovery through threat mitigation at landscape level in Eastern Ghats of Andhra Pradesh, India

description.narrative: A recent assessment of tiger populations in the Eastern Ghats of Andhra Pradesh, helped identify new corridors, with tigers presumably dispersing from breeding populations within Nagarjunasagar Srisailam tiger reserve (NSTR) and Gundla Brameshwaram Wildlife Sanctuary (GBM). There is an urgent need to secure newly identified landscapes south of GBM where tigers likely disperse from NSTR and GBM. Therefore, it is essential to identify critical dispersal corridors and intensify tiger monitoring in the new landscapes. The project aims to increase tiger densities at NSTR and ensure survival of tigers in the immediate corridors outside designated tiger reserves. Project objectives are: (1) To identify and map threats to tigers and prey species; (2) Mitigate threats by involving government agencies and local communities in the tiger landscape of the Eastern Ghats; (3) Aid in consolidating tiger habitats within tiger reserves by promoting government schemes; and, (4) Provide scientific and conservation support to the Andhra Pradesh Forest Department.

title.narrative: Forest Department-Community partnership to improve protection of Western Hoolock Gibbons (Hoolock hoolock) in Jeypore RF, India - Phase VI

description.narrative: The Jeypore Range of Dibrugarh Forest Division has a shortage of the manpower required to protect this area, even though infrastructure, i.e., guard posts exist at strategic locations. The Roving Gibbon Patrol Units (RGPUs) has the following features: the active involvement of local community members in forest patrolling widely held not to be a workable model in India; organized anti-poaching patrolling in an area that is largely a Reserve Forest and not yet fully a Protected Area or Tiger Reserve; the flexibility of the units to move between camps as necessary and in response to changing threat perceptions; the first project in Northeast India to use SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrols developed by the Global Tiger Initiative for enhanced law enforcement monitoring. The project objectives are to: (1) Continue the operations of the three roving gibbon and wildlife patrol units comprising of 3 community members and headed by a forest guard in each group; and, (2) Implement SMART patrolling protocols; systematically record patrol details and produce monthly reports; plan future patrols using these reports.

title.narrative: A study to understand the pervasive threat of exploitation and trade of Indian Pangolin and Theraphosid spiders and to involve local community in species and habitat conservation through education

description.narrative: The genus Poecilotheria of the tarantula family Theraphosidae has 14 species in the world and seven of these are endemic to India. All species are threatened by illegal harvesting of adult tarantulas for the pet trade and habitat loss. There is currently a lack of information on the extent of these threats and their impacts to the overall population. To fill this gap and address the illegal harvesting of tarantulas for the pet trade in Tamil Nadu, this two-year grant will support: interviews with local community members in 52 villages in Tamil Nadu to assess the existing trade and ongoing threats to tarantulas in the Western Ghats; assessment of the habitat quality and rate of species decline; development of a conservation education program for select local communities (approximately 10,000 people) living in the Western Ghats to create awareness about the importance of tarantulas and the need for conservation; establishment of a diverse network, including universities and local communities, to secure engagement on tarantula conservation at multiple levels in India; and development of a short video on the threats facing tarantulas and importance of protecting these species.

title.narrative: Strengthen the protection measures in Manas National Park as a part of the program Indian Rhino Vision 2020 to expand the numbers and range of wild rhinos in Assam, India, Phase-XII

description.narrative: The entire Indian rhino population of Manas National Park (MNP) numbering around 100 was poached in the 1990s. Only two of the greater one-horned rhinoceros (Rhinoceros unicornis) bearing protected areas' populations (Kaziranga National Park in India, and Chitwan National Park in Nepal) have more than 100 individuals. To prevent extinction from any catastrophic event, the Assam Forest Department and the various NGOs agreed to range expansion of the rhino in Assam through translocations from Kaziranga and Pobitora (another Park with a healthy population of rhino) to other appropriate protected areas (PAs), under Indian Rhino Vision 2020. Improvement of MNP security was the prime objective for rhino translocation to MNP. Manas National Park now has 30 rhinos including the newborns, but, poaching is still a serious threat. Project objectives are to: (1) Support the salary of 15 guards for 12 months; (2) Select guards from villages adjacent to MNP to improve their socioeconomic status, and foster good relation between the MNP management and the fringe villagers; and, (3) Provide special training of the newly recruited guards on wildlife conservation and to combat poaching.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF TIGER AND ITS HABITAT THROUGH UNIQUE LAW ENFORCEMENT AND LIVELIHOOD MODEL SUPPORT IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK

description.narrative: The Manas National Park (MNP) management through its Manas Tigers smart protection programs identifies Illegal Natural Resource Extractors (INRE) and warns them about their repeat illegal activities in the MNP. These INRE are then introduced to Aaranyak livelihood program to support them with alternative sustainable livelihood. So far 1400 households have been covered under this program. This project plans to support 100 INRE, thus further securing the MNP and removing direct threats to tigers, rhinoceros and Asian elephants. Project objectives are, (1) Strengthen protection in MNP using Manas Tigers protection model; (2) Reduce human disturbance in the park by reducing dependence of 100 INRE using alternative farm and non-farm livelihood options; and, (3) Monitor and evaluate impacts of conservation interventions on the ground using sets of indicators.

title.narrative: Developing mitigation strategies to Tiger-Rhino and other wildlife-vehicle collisions in Kaziranga Tiger Reserve, Assam

description.narrative: Kaziranga National Park (KNP), is a critical protected area in India for rhinos, tigers, Asian elephants and other endangered wildlife. Nearly 60 kilometers of the National Highway 37 (NH 37) passes adjacent to KNP, and it is at least 7.5 meters wide. Extensive flooding during the rainy season increases wildlife crossings of NH 37. The adverse consequences to wildlife from 2- to 4-lane highway expansion include, increased vehicular traffic volumes increasing wildlife-vehicle collisions, a barrier to animal crossing, and, the road widening rendering the existing at-grade crossings of the key elephant corridors potentially ineffective. Project objectives are to, (1) Identify and prioritize highway stretches that require mitigation measures to reduce wildlife-vehicle collisions and provide safe crossing for wildlife based on: (i) crash and carcass data, (ii) observation data of wildlife seen alive on and along the highway segments, and, (iii) maps and local expert knowledge of important wildlife habitat and corridors bisected by the NH 37; (2) Recommend mitigation measures for wildlife at the selected locations; and, (3) Conduct cost-estimate analyses for a range of mitigation measures for the selected highway segments.

title.narrative: Prioritizing conservation landscapes for the Asian elephant in Assam, Northeast India

description.narrative: This project will work to ensure that the northeastern state of Assam, India retains threat-free interconnected populations of wild Asian elephants. This project will work in collaboration with the Assam Forest Department to obtain a comprehensive status assessment of the elephants in multiple conservation landscapes in Assam and use this information to collaboratively draft an implementable action plan for the species. Project objectives include: 1) assess elephant distribution and habitat across Assam; 2) map threat distribution; and 3) prioritize conservation action and areas for wild elephants. Specific project activities include: 1) develop a reliable and feasible protocol for a comprehensive status assessment of elephants; 2) map extant habitat and critical corridors for the species across Assam; 3) conduct an elephant distribution and threats survey; 4) identify areas of humanelephant conflict and non-natural mortality; 5) conduct stakeholder workshops for capacity building, dissemination of knowledge and formulation of action plans; and 6) draft a state-wide landscape-scale conservation action plan for elephants in collaboration with the State Government and other stakeholders. This will be the first statewide conservation status assessment for elephants in Assam, and lead to the development of a protocol for such assessments that is replicable across the species range.

title.narrative: Securing Asian elephant habitats and populations in Kerala, South India through a Government endorsed, comprehensive, landscape-scale conservation plan

description.narrative: This project will work collaboratively with the Kerala Forests and Wildlife Department to ensure that the southern state of Kerala, India retains threat-free interconnected populations of wild Asian elephants. The objective of this project is a comprehensive status assessment of wild elephants in multiple conservation landscapes in Kerala and using this information to prioritize conservation efforts for the species. Specific objectives include: 1) assess the distribution of the Asian elephant and its habitat across Kerala; 2) conduct a threats assessment; and 3) draft an action plan for elephants in Kerala. Project activities include: 1) map extant habitat using remote sensing imagery; 2) scientific surveys of elephant presence; 3) model habitat connectivity for the species across Kerala; 4) identify conflict hotspots and zones of increased non-natural mortality; and 5) in consultation with the Government of Kerala draft a statewide landscape-scale conservation action plan for elephants. This project will lead to effective and tangible conservation of Asian elephants in Kerala, a globally important region for this species.

title.narrative: My elephant in my village: empowering local communities with site-specific strategies to mitigate human-elephant conflict

description.narrative: The primary goal of this two-year project is to conserve Asian elephants in a human-dominated landscape by adopting village-level land use, agricultural and lifestyle practices that are also compatible with elephant use of the landscape. Project objectives include: 1) form and train village teams to manage HEC; 2) train and implement site-specific farm-based practices to reduce HEC; 3) establish and maintain physical structures to reduce HEC; 4) deploy technology to equip villagers with an early warning system; and 5) develop a framework for site-specific implementation of mitigation action plans at the village level. Project activities include: 1) identify and train villagers who will form village protection squads, with specific duties and pay; 2) identify and implement agricultural and livestock management practices to reduce HEC while taking into consideration the behavior of elephants and in consultation with village agriculture extension officers; 3) construction and maintenance of watch towers and procurement of equipment for anti-crop depredation activities and crop-guarding; 4) deployment of an elephant early-warning system; 5) preparation and distribution of an illustrated handbook for each village covering the crop life cycle and livestock management practices unique to each village.

title.narrative: Enhancing elephant conservation in the Trans-boundary Manas Conservation Area (TraMCA): An Indo-Bhutan initiative

description.narrative: The Transboundary Manas Conservation Area forms a priority landscape with an area of over 3,000 sq km. It is one of three transboundary landscapes across the Eastern Himalayas that connect Bhutan and Northeast India. The landscape faces growing threats linked to increases human populations and illegal activities, including the porous border between Bhutan and India which facilitates the poaching and trafficking of elephants. Project activities will include: 1) identify transboundary elephant migration routes and patterns; 2) based on elephant landscape usage, identify priority locations for new anti-poaching camps for the use of forest department staff; 3) conduct five joint training programs on elephant population estimations, in for forest department staff of both India and Bhutan; 4) conduct joint surveys on elephant presence/absence across the entire landscape; 5) conduct vegetation transect surveys; 6) organize two workshops with involvement of all stakeholders and local villagers to develop anti-poaching strategies; and 7) using GIS to create a landscape corridor and elephant movement map. This project will enhance transboundary collaboration on elephant conservation and population monitoring between Indian and Bhutanese authorities in the Transboundary Manas Conservation Area of Bhutan and India.

title.narrative: Action based conservation approach to prevent electrocution of Asian elephants in Assam

description.narrative: The state of Assam, in northeast India, is home to over 6,000 wild Asian elephants which are threatened by poaching, habitat loss, human-elephant conflict, and electrocution - both accidental and intentional. This project will focus on assessing the mortality of wild Asian elephants by electrocution in Assam over the last year and determining the circumstances and location of each electrocution. Locations where elephants come into contact with high-voltage power lines in the state will be mapped and a workshop with the Assam Power Distribution Company Limited, the government power board, will be organized to prepare a standard operating procedure. Actions will be recommended for target areas, including the insulation of power lines in areas where elephants may come into contact with live wires and elevation of low-hanging wires in areas where elephants migrate to prevent elephant fatalities by electrocution. An action plan will be prepared with the government to prevent electrocution deaths. This project will significantly contribute to the ongoing conservation efforts for Asian elephants in Assam by reducing the chances of accidental and intentional electrocution.

title.narrative: Continue Community Based Sea Turtle Conservation Program and Integrate Related Enforcement Departments for Better Advocacy in Andhra Pradesh and Odisha, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conduct community based sea turtle conservation projects along nesting beaches on the Bay of Bengal, India. The intent of this project is to protect nests and nesting turtles (primarily olive ridelys) from poaching and reduce the accidental capture and mortality of sea turtles in fishing trawls. Activities include: (1) members of Sea Turtle Community Force teams will conduct daily surveys to protect nests and nesting turtles along over 500 km encompassing 173 villages during the December to May nesting season and protect an estimated 6000 nests; (2) outreach and education will be conducted in 111 fishing communities to address sea turtle bycatch impacting the major olive ridley arribada nesting populations in the State of Orissa, India; (3) capacity building workshops to train 1000 enforcement officers from wildlife and fisheries institutions, Coast Guard and Marine Police in the laws and regulations protecting marine life and systems and to strengthen collaboration among the institutions; and (4) conduct joint TED demonstration workshops for trawl fisheries with Fisheries and Forestry Dept.

title.narrative: PEOPLE FOR SNOW LEOPARDS: LOCAL COMMUNITY ACTION INTEGRATED WITH NATIONAL AND GLOBAL STRATEGIES TO COMBAT ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter snow leopard trafficking in the mountains of Asia by piloting a community-based anti-poaching model with and for communities. This project is intended to conserve snow leopards in northern India by addressing the impacts of poaching and retribution killing. Specific activities include: (1) training local rangers and community champions for improved response and support during situations related to illegal killing or trafficking; (2) creating a wildlife trafficking community hotline and response team; (3) providing awareness and outreach materials to communities about wildlife laws and anti-crime resources; and (4) helping communities pledge to support and take ownership over anti-hunting measures.

title.narrative: Hoolock gibbon survey to identify their current status and viable population for conservation in eastern Assam, India

description.narrative: Habitat loss and fragmentation along with illegal hunting have been identified as primary threats for gibbons in Assam and other Northeastern Indian states. The Assam Forest Department is interested in upgrading the potential forest pockets to wildlife sanctuary with gibbon as flagship species for conservation of gibbon along with the rich bio-diversity in the proposed study area. This study will identify potential areas which can be upgraded to Wildlife Sanctuary for future conservation of gibbon in particular and other wildlife in general. Project objectives are: (1)To know the current population status of Hoolock gibbon in 20 Reserve Forests in Doomdooma Forest Division; (2) Identification of threats; (3) Capacity development of forest staff; and, (4)To provide the baseline information to Assam Forest Department for up gradation of potential gibbon habitat to wildlife Sanctuary.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING LAW ENFORCEMENT AND IMPROVING AWARENESS FOR CONSERVATION OF PANGOLINS, STAR TORTOISES, AND OTHER LESSER KNOWN SPECIES IN ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE IN PENINSULAR INDIA

description.narrative: India is a significant source and transit country for illegal wildlife products. Traditionally, wildlife law enforcement efforts have focused on the trade in large mammals such as tigers and elephants. The purpose of this project is to combat poaching and illegal wildlife trade of lesser known species in the Western and Eastern Ghats of India, including the Indian pangolin (Manis crassicaudata) and Indian star tortoise (Geochelone elegans). To address the illegal killing and trafficking of these species, this two-year grant will support: (1) data gathering on the prevalence of poaching of lesser known species, including using seizure records to map poaching hotspots, trafficking networks, routes, and major hubs; (2) strengthening law enforcement through interagency training and exchange among key governmental partners in India including the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau, Enforcement Directorate, Directorate of Revenue Intelligence, and state Forest Departments; (3) training workshops for the judiciary to increase conviction rates in wildlife trafficking cases; and (4) developing a constituency for conservation through awareness raising activities among policymakers and local communities.

title.narrative: Ecology and Conservation of the Hoolock Gibbon (Hoolock hoolock) in Bangladesh

description.narrative: Hoolock Gibbons (Hoolock hoolock) are among the most threatened small apes in the world. Because they live in densely populated northeastern India, Bangladesh and western Myanmar, their current status globally is endangered. Population estimates and habitat information are limited for the species. Less than 300 species were estimated to live in scattered forest fragments in Bangladesh in the early 2000s. These numbers have persisted and much needs to be done to allow them to continue. This project proposes to estimate the population size of Hoolock Gibbons in all known areas in Bangladesh, provide detailed habitat quality data and establish the role of Hoolock Gibbons in maintaining forest integrity. Hoolock Gibbon home ranges and movement patterns will be quantified to determine how they allocate time during their activities. Forest Department staff will be trained to collect and manage data. Field guides will be trained to provide small group tours. Public education sessions will be held, with visits to schools and interviews at media outlets to make people aware of the precarious state of the Hoolock Gibbon in Bangladesh and their important role in forest regeneration. Research papers will be published, several reports will be produced to aid the Bangladesh Government to allocate funds to establish protection measures.

Activities include: (1) conducting an.annual census of the large olive ridley mass nesting population at Rushikulya with partners; (2) strengthening a program to.monitor and protect the leatherback nesting colony in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands; (3) conducting training programs for.capacity building of a network of organizations called the Turtle Action Group (TAG) to improve organizational strengths and.conservation impacts; and (4) designing and developing educational materials and displays in collaboration with the Forest.Department.

title.narrative: TRANSFORMING HUMAN-ELEPHANT INTERACTIONS THROUGH COMPENSATION, EDUCATION AND MITIGATION AROUND INDIA S WESTERN GHATS.

description.narrative: The goal of this three-year project is to increase local peoples tolerance and build long term support for Asian elephants in shared landscapes, through compensation, mitigation, and education in high conflict zones surrounding important elephant reserves in the Western Ghats of India. Human-elephant conflict (HEC) is severe in India resulting in crop loss and property damage, human injury, and death. The Wild Seve initiative assists victims with the government compensation process by using mobile technology to file and track claims. The Wild Shaale conservation education program fosters local interest and affinity for wildlife, particularly conflict prone elephants and tigers, builds tolerance, and provides basic coping mechanisms to vulnerable families. This project expands these two initiatives and will: 1) expand Wild Seve to 300 villages and 50,000 people; 2) file 15,000+ HEC claims across five wildlife reserves; 3) implement Wild Shaale in 150 high conflict village schools reaching 11,000 children; 4) assess attitudes and build community awareness in 30 villages; 5) recruit and train 8 staff in conflict response and 9 educator and evaluator teams.

title.narrative: LANDSCAPE APPROACH TO CONSERVE ASIAN ELEPHANTS IN NORTHEAST INDIA WITH PARTICULAR FOCUS TO ASSAM AND MEGHALAYA, INDIA.

description.narrative: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE WILD ASIAN ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITATS IN NORTHEAST INDIA VIA EMPIRICAL RESEARCH, FACILITATION OF HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE (HECX), AND OUTREACH AND SUPPORT TO STAKEHOLDERS. THE PROJECT HAS FOUR MAJOR OBJECTIVES, WHICH IMPACT BOTH LANDSCAPE AND LOCAL LEVEL CONSERVATION IN NORTHEAST INDIA (1) TO UNDERSTAND DISTRIBUTION, MOVEMENT, AND GENETIC CONNECTIVITY OF ELEPHANT POPULATIONS AND USE THAT DATA TO INFORM CONSERVATION DECISION MAKING AND POPULATION MANAGEMENT (2) TO MITIGATE HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) AND FACILITATE HECX (3) TO PROVIDE OUTREACH AND CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT AND (4) TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO FOREST DEPARTMENT AND PROTECTED AREA OFFICIALS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) NON 1 INVASIVE ELEPHANT DNA COLLECTION, EXTRACTION, SEQUENCING, MULTI LOCUS MICROSATELLITE GENOTYPING, ANALYSIS TO ASSESS GENETIC DIVERSITY, POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTURE, AND GENE FLOW (2) OCCUPANCY MODELLING OF ELEPHANT DISTRIBUTION IN MEGHALAYA USING DUNG COUNTS, PHOTOGRAPHIC MARK RECAPTURE, AND GENETIC SAMPLING (3) ASSESSMENT OF INTERSTATE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AMONG MEGHALAYA, ARUNACHAL PRADESH, MIZORAM, ASSAM, AND NAGALAND WITH GIS ANALYSIS, GROUND TRUTHING, SURVEYS OF LOCAL RESIDENTS, AND CONSULTATIONS WITH STATE FOREST AND ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIALS (4) DEVELOPING A HABITAT RESTORATIO

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to conserve wild Asian elephants and their habitats in Northeast India via empirical research, facilitation of human-elephant coexistence (HECx), and outreach and support to stakeholders. The project has four major objectives, which impact both landscape- and local-level conservation in Northeast India: (1) to understand distribution, movement, and genetic connectivity of elephant populations and use that data to inform conservation decision-making and population management; (2) to mitigate human-elephant conflict (HEC) and facilitate HECx; (3) to provide outreach and capacity development; and (4) to provide support to Forest Department and protected area officials. Project activities include: (1) non.invasive elephant DNA collection, extraction, sequencing, multi-locus microsatellite genotyping, analysis to assess genetic diversity, population genetic structure, and gene flow; (2) occupancy modelling of elephant distribution in Meghalaya using dung counts, photographic mark-recapture, and genetic sampling; (3) assessment of interstate habitat connectivity among Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh, Mizoram, Assam, and Nagaland with GIS analysis, ground truthing, surveys of local residents, and consultations with state forest and administrative officials; (4) developing a habitat restoration plan and map identifying potential habitat for elephants outside of protected areas by assessing sites using satellite images, ground truthing, and surveys of anthropogenic pressures; (5) reducing electrocution of elephants by tracking and ground-truthing electrocution deaths, identifying sites in high-conflict zones where illegal electric fences are operated, conducting consultative workshops with local residents, Forest and Civil Administration Departments, and converting illegal fences to non-fatal solar-powered fences; (6) consulting with private tea garden estates to minimize HEC and introduce to HEC mitigation tools and best practices; (7) facilitating

title.narrative: BACK ON TRACK: PREVENTING TRAIN-ELEPHANT COLLISIONS IN ASSAM, INDIA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to minimize train-elephant collisions in Assam, India and foster the development of Indian Railways systems that prevent train-elephant collisions. Project objectives are to: (1) assess the vulnerabilities of four sections (162 km) of track that account for 75% of prior train-elephant collisions in Assam; (2) provide data-driven recommendations for minimizing the risk of train-elephant collisions in high-risk sections of track; and (3) support the implementation of recommendations to minimize train-elephant collisions. Project activities are to: (1) examine high-risk sections of track via joint surveys with officials from the Railways and Forest Departments; (2) better understand Indian Railways traffic control systems through interviews of railway personnel and direct observations of train control room operations; (3) use video camera traps to monitor elephant crossing points on railroad tracks; (4) make, evaluate, and finalize recommendations to reduce elephant-train collisions via multistakeholder engagements and field visits; (5) revise and finalize recommendations and secure necessary institutional commitment through multi-level stakeholder engagement; (6) conduct workshops with stakeholders to raise awareness of recommendations and implementation plans; and (7) collaborate with key officials as per due process of the Indian Railways and Forest Departments to implement, develop, and test novel interventions.

title.narrative: WILD SEVE: ADDRESSING HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT IN INDIA'S WESTERN GHATS TIGER RESERVES

description.narrative: The Wild Seve program (Seve stands for service in Kannada) is an early human-wildlife conflict response program to ensure.expedited action during incidents involving crop loss, property damage, livestock loss, human injury, or death. Using a web.portal, toll-free helpline and SMS reporting system, Centre for Wildlife Studies has created a local response system with their.field staff, who arrive on site and assist with evaluating and filing claims. Data collected on the Wild Connect platform allows.responders to collect data even when internet connections are not available. The purpose of this project is to (1) Establish and.expand Wild Seve presence around 1200-1500 village settlements surrounding 12 tiger reserves in Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil.Nadu over 5 years; (2) Assist in filing claims related to tiger conflict around 12 tiger reserves over 5 years; (3) Mitigate human.big cat conflict through 325 predator-proof sheds and other tools; and (4) Implement 300 Wild Surakshe public safety and.awareness workshops on tiger conflict, engaging 15,000 frontline government staff and community leaders

title.narrative: ELEPHANTS WITHOUT BORDERS: ECOLOGY, CONSERVATION AND CONFLICT MANAGEMENT OF ELEPHANTS IN SOUTHERN NILGIRIS.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to initiate a long-term elephant monitoring program in a human-dominated area of the greater Nilgiris-Eastern Ghats Elephant Landscape, specifically to assess wild Asian elephant populations, movement, habitat use, and patterns of human-elephant conflict (HEC) in Tamil Nadu and Kerala, India. Specific objectives are to: (1) better understand the elephant populations of the Southern Nilgiris landscape; (2) assess spatiotemporal patterns and local communities attitudes and tolerance of HEC; (3) ascertain the drivers of HEC in the landscape; and (4) test and establish elephant detection systems. Project activities are to: (1) conduct a landscape-level elephant sign survey to assess seasonal distribution and habitat use; (2) undertake camera trap surveys to assess population structure; (3) conduct a ground-based assessment of property damage, crop loss, injury, and deaths related to HEC; (4) conduct household surveys to assess attitudes and direct and indirect impacts of HEC and mitigation measures; (5) map all HEC mitigations currently used in the landscape, including investment and maintenance costs; (6) assess the efficacy of HEC mitigation measures by measuring the results of various interventions; (7) conduct dung-based hormone analysis to measure the nutritional stress of elephants; (8) assess and map threats and anthropogenic disturbances to elephant habitat; (9) trial a prototype acoustic-based elephant detection device; (10) deploy the acoustic-detection system in the field; (11) dissemination of results to government officials, policy makers, and social media platforms; (12) community outreach including workshops and focus groups in high-conflict villages; and (13) recommendation of site-specific HEC mitigation measures.

title.narrative: AMPLIFYING ASIAN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION THROUGH CAPACITY BUILDING AND SENSITIZATION PROGRAMS IN TAMIL NADU, INDIA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to ensure the long-term survival of Asian elephant populations by minimizing human-elephant conflict (HEC) and promote the peaceful survival of both elephants and humans in Tamil Nadu, India. The project will conduct HEC capacity building training for frontline forest staff and to administer human-elephant coexistence (HECx) sensitization programs for media and government staff in Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve and the recently declared Srivilliputhur-Megamalai Tiger Reserve. In partnership with the Tamil Nadu Forest Department, the recipient will conduct trainings and workshops for frontline forest staff, forest range officers, and newly hired park staff, journalists, lawyers, local police, and other stakeholders in both protected areas. Specific activities include: (1) conduct two two-day training programs for 60 frontline staff on HEC and HEC mitigation; (2) conduct two one-day sensitization programs for 50 participants, including journalists, lawyers, local police, and other forest department staff; and (3) evaluation of the impacts of the two programs and creation of a communication network among participants for information sharing.

title.narrative: CONTINUE COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION AND ENSURE STAKEHOLDER STEWARDSHIP TO CONSERVE SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS, ALONG ANDHRA PRADESH AND ODISHA, INDIA

description.narrative: This project will conduct community-based sea turtle conservation projects along nesting beaches on the Bay of Bengal, India to protect olive ridley nests and nesting turtles from poaching and reduce the accidental capture and mortality of sea turtles in fishing trawls. Activities include: (1) members of Sea Turtle Community Force teams will conduct daily surveys to protect nests and nesting turtles along over 500 km encompassing 173 villages during the December to May nesting season and protect an estimated 6,000 nests; (2) outreach and education will be conducted in 171 fishing communities to address sea turtle bycatch impacting the major olive ridley arribada nesting populations in the State of Orissa, India; 3) capacity building workshops will be held to train more than 1,000 enforcement officers from wildlife and fisheries institutions, Coast Guard and Marine Police in the laws and regulations protecting marine life and systems and to strengthen collaboration among the institutions; and 4) joint Turtle Exclusion Device (TED) demonstration workshops will be conducted for trawl fisheries with the Fisheries and Forestry Departments.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) Provide comprehensive support to marginalized families residing outside Protected Areas (PAs) towards improving their socio-economic status and minimizing their dependence on forest resources to facilitate the recovery of tiger and prey populations in these forests. This support will include assistance with access to benefits under various government schemes to assist in economic development, organizing training programs for these families on income generation programs and providing guidance on improved farming techniques, and providing these families with seeds, saplings and agricultural supplies; (2) Support the forest department and other government departments in the management, conservation and ecological monitoring of tiger and prey populations as well as their habitats; and (3) Strengthen stewardship for forests and wildlife among rural communities living adjacent to wildlife and wildlife habitats.

title.narrative: INSTITUTIONALIZING COMMUNITY-BASED MANAGEMENT OF ELEPHANT CONFLICT AND STRENGTHENING MANAGEMENT OF DANDELI ELEPHANT RESERVE BY PARTNERSHIP WITH FOREST DEPARTMENTS AND LOCAL SELF-GOVERNANCE BODIES, KAR

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to institutionalize and strengthen a participatory model of.managing human-elephant conflict in the North Karnara Southern Maharashtra landscape by.empowering local farmers to protect their crops using simple, low-tech solutions and to implement sound.management practices in Dandeli Elephant Reserve and Southern Maharashtra, India. Project objective.and activities are to: (1) institutionalize the Community-Based Conflict Management in Village Forest.Committees and Eco-Development Committees of the Forest Department using a participatory rural.appraisal process in 80 new villages; (2) introduce technology-based solutions for HEC management.including an infrared sensor-based elephant alert system, solar flicker lights, and use of a smartphone app.previously developed with US Fish and Wildlife Service funding; (3) use an SMS alert system to receive.and send alerts of elephant presence in villages; (4) identify individual elephants using photographic.capture-recapture methodology and undertake an analysis of population size; (5) prepare a management.plan for Dandeli Elephant Reserve based on mapping land use, potential for alternative crops, surveys.local residents of perception of elephant conservation, and consultations with Forest Department officials.and frontline staff; (6) support the Forest Department in implementation of the management plan; and (7).assist in the implementation of habitat restoration in Dandeli Elephant Reserve by conducting trials on the.removal of the invasive plant Chromolaena odorata which outcompetes native species and reduces.availability of species palatable to elephants.

title.narrative: CAPABLE AND FUNCTIONAL ELEPHANTS: A CAPABILITIES APPROACH FOR MITIGATING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT IN THE BRAHMAGIRI-NILGIRI-EASTERN GHATS LANDSCAPE OF SOUTHERN INDIA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to develop a landscape-level plan for the mitigation of human.elephant conflict (HEC) that is based on an assessment of capabilities and functionings of agriculturists.and elephants in the Brahmagiri-Nilgiri-Eastern Ghats Landscape (BNEGL) of southern India. Project.objectives are to: (1) map the current set of basic capabilities and functionings of agriculturists and.elephants; (2) model future sets of basic capabilities and functionings of agriculturists and elephants; (3).identify current and future sets of unrealized functioning of agriculturists and elephants due to HEC; (4).identify appropriate HEC measures that minimize unrealized functioning of agriculturists and elephants;.and (5) build capacity and disseminate information. Project activities are to: (1) use village-level census.data, land-use land-cover (LULC) modeling, questionnaires, surveys, focal group discussions, and.mapping to assess the capability of agriculturists to achieve basic functionings; (2) analyze existing.literature on elephant abundance, density estimates and demography at the range/division level, model.their movement using NetLogo and assess elephant abundance and demography in select elephant.habitats to derive the set of capabilities that aid attainment of their basic functionings; (3) derive the basic.capabilities and functionings of agriculturalists and the patterns of occurrence of elephants in the future.through LULC modeling; (4) identify of the current and future set of unrealized functionings of.agriculturists and elephants due to HEC, as determined by the overlapping land use of agriculturists and.elephants; (5) identify and assess the efficacy of current and future HEC mitigations; (6) conduct.workshops to identify and recommend technology and policy gaps that can improve HEC mitigation.measures to enhance the capabilities of agriculturists and elephants; (7) conduct workshops for decision.makers to plan, share results, develop an illustrated loc

title.narrative: FOREST DEPARTMENT-COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE PROTECTION OF WESTERN HOOLOCK GIBBONS HOOLOCK IN JEYPORE, RF, INDIA -PHASE VIII

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue to support (1) the systematic field anti-poaching operations of three Roving Gibbon.Patrol Units (RGPU), each comprising of three community members and headed by a forest guard; (2) data reporting by RGPUs.and the maintenance of patrolling records by the Project Monitoring Assistant (PMA). The PMA will continue to compile the data.and produce monthly reports with maps, based upon which the field officer (Range Officer) will plan adaptive actions in.consultation with the RGPU; (3) compile, analyze and summarize all records from Phase I to Phase VIII in Year 3 of the project.to document total effort, challenges, outcomes, and lessons learned from this collaborative conservation model; and (4) a.systematic survey of hoolock gibbons using call and sightings in Year 2 of the project to estimate the gibbon population in.Jeypore.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reinforce national efforts to curb wildlife crime involving endangered.species, particularly against tigers, across India. The project objectives are to efficiently facilitate.enforcement action against wildlife crime throughout India by gathering and disseminating an updated.and systematic data analysis that is utilized to disrupt wildlife criminal networks across India. Activities.include collecting and verifying relevant leads on wildlife crime, updating the existing database with.country-wide statistics, analyzing wildlife crime trends using i2 software, providing inputs and assistance.to enforcement agencies, disseminating information to strengthen policy, and monitoring development of.this exclusive database.

title.narrative: GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT FOR REPLENISHING HABITATS TO BOOST CONSERVATION OF RHINO AND TIGER IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK AND POBITORA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY IN ASSAM, INDIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE GRASSLAND HABITAT FOR THE SURVIVAL OF GRASSLAND DEPENDENT THREATENED SPECIES, SUCH AS THE GREATER ONE HORNED RHINO, HOG DEER, SWAMP DEER, HISPID HARE, PYGMY HOG, ASIATIC WATER BUFFALO, TIGER, ELEPHANT, BENGAL FLORICAN, SWAMP FRANCOLIN, AND ACT AS A MODEL FOR GRASSLAND RESTORATION ACROSS THE REGION. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF INVASIVE PLANTS SPECIES AND IDENTIFY THE PRIMARY DRIVERS OF THEIR INVASION IN POBITORA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY (2) IMPLEMENT AND VALIDATE APPROPRIATE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL METHODS IN POBITORA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY (3) CONTINUE THE MONITORING OF INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEM OF MANAS NATIONAL PARK (MNP) AND RESTORE 20 SQ KM OF INVADED GRASSLAND (4) BUILD CAPACITY OF FRONTLINE STAFF IN RHINO BEARING AREAS ON GRASSLAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT (5) PROMOTE USES OF INVASIVE SPECIES FOR ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD THROUGH COORDINATION WITH AND SUPPORT FOR SELF HELP GROUPS IN EASTERN MANAS AND (6) REDUCE GRASSLAND DEGRADATION AND INCURSION IN MNP THROUGH THE PILOTING AND PROMOTION OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS AND IMPROVEMENT IN LIVESTOCK HUSBANDRY PRACTICES AND LIVESTOCK VACCINATION, IN COORDINATION WITH THE ECO DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEES IN CENTRAL MANAS.

title.narrative: GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT FOR REPLENISHING HABITATS TO BOOST CONSERVATION OF RHINO AND TIGER IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK AND POBITORA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY IN ASSAM, INDIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conserve and restore grassland habitat for the survival of grassland dependent threatened species, such as the greater one horned rhino, hog deer, swamp deer, hispid hare, pygmy hog, Asiatic water buffalo, tiger, elephant, Bengal florican, Swamp francolin, and act as a model for grassland restoration across the region. The objectives are to (1) understand the current status and distribution of invasive plants species and identify the primary drivers of their invasion in Pobitora Wildlife Sanctuary; (2) implement and validate appropriate invasive species control methods in Pobitora Wildlife Sanctuary; (3) continue the monitoring of invasive species in the grassland ecosystem of Manas National Park (MNP) and restore 20 sq km of invaded grassland; (4) build capacity of frontline staff in rhino bearing areas on grassland habitat management; (5) promote uses of invasive species for alternative livelihood through coordination with and support for Self Help Groups in Eastern Manas; and (6) reduce grassland degradation and incursion in MNP through the piloting and promotion of alternative livelihoods and improvement in livestock husbandry practices and livestock vaccination, in coordination with the Eco Development Committees in Central Manas.

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS ENHANCING THE CONSERVATION OF TIGERS, ASIAN RHINOS, AND OTHER ENDANGERED WILDLIFE IN ASIA THROUGH IMPROVED VETERINARY CAPACITY IN THE RANGE COUNTRIES BY IMPARTING KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO LOCAL VETERINARIANS IN DISEASE INVESTIGATION, SURVEILLANCE, AND OTHER CONSERVATION THREATS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS 1 IDENTIFY LOCAL AND OUT OF REGION SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS IN WILDLIFE VETERINARY MEDICINE, VETERINARY PATHOLOGY, EPIDEMIOLOGY, ECOLOGY, AND WILDLIFE POPULATION MANAGEMENT 2 HOST ONLINE VIDEO CONFERENCES IN 2022 FOR WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS WITH SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO ESTABLISH NETWORKING, ASSESS THE NEEDS OF WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS AND DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS FOR IMPROVED DISEASE INVESTIGATION AND SURVEILLANCE 3 HOST HANDS-ON LABORATORY TRAINING SESSIONS AT THE CENTRE FOR WILDLIFE RESEARCH AND FORENSICS INDIA , AND AT THE NTNC BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION CENTRE LABORATORY NEPAL IN 2023 AND 4 SUPPORT 10 VETERINARIANS TO TRAVEL TO AND PARTICIPATE IN THE ONE WEEK FIVE DAYS HANDS-ON FIELD TRAINING COURSES IN EACH OF THE TWO LABORATORIES IN ORDER TO BUILD THEIR INDIVIDUAL CAPACITY AND ENHANCE THEIR WILDLIFE VETERINARY EXPERTISE TO MORE EFFECTIVELY INVESTIGATE AND MONITOR DISEASE AND ASSIST CONSERVATION EFFORTS.

title.narrative: DETERRING WILDLIFE CRIME AND ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING OF RHINOCEROS AND TIGER BODY PARTS IN THE TRANSBOUNDARY EASTERN HIMALAYAS

description.narrative: The overall goal of this project is to check and reduce wildlife crime and illegal wildlife trade of rhinoceros and tiger by 2024..The project objectives are as follows: (1) Increase effectiveness of law enforcement agencies by strengthening their tools, and.capacity to check and reduce wildlife crime and illegal wildlife trade of rhino and tigers by 2024; (2) Generate, collate, and share.information on illegal wildlife trade hotspots and pathways in the eastern Himalayas with relevant law enforcement agencies to.trigger needed legal action to curb wildlife crime on rhino and tiger body parts and other threatened wildlife; (3) Establish a.community-based surveillance, monitoring and wildlife crime prevention system in collaboration with law enforcement agencies.in Assam, Arunachal Pradesh and Manipur, to reduce the site level illegal wildlife offences targeting rhinos, tigers and other.threatened animals by 2024; and (4) Establish two novel transboundary collaborations to reduce transnational organized crime on.rhinoceros, tigers and other key species.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING CONSERVATION OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS, PREY ANIMALS, HABITATS AND BIOLOGICAL CORRIDORS IN THE TRANSBOUNDARY MANAS LANDSCAPE, INDIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUSTAIN THE RECOVERY OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND THEIR PREY ACROSS TRANSBOUNDARY MANAS CONSERVATION AREA OF INDIA. THE OBJECTIVES AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES ARE AS FOLLOWS 1 IDENTIFYING THE RECOVERY POTENTIAL FOR TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY RECOVERY IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE ACTIVITIES 1.1 SET BASELINES FOR POPULATION AND COMMUNITY STRUCTURE OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY IN THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE IN INDIA 1.2 BUILD FIELD AND ANALYTICAL CAPACITY AMONGST PARK MANAGEMENT AND GRASSROOTS NGO VOLUNTEERS TO CONDUCT AND ANALYZE BIOLOGICAL MONITORING INFORMATION FOR SUSTAINED RECOVERY 2 DEVELOPING A COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN TO SECURE FUTURE TIGER, CO-PREDATOR AND PREY POPULATIONS ACTIVITIES 2.1 DEVELOP A TIGER, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY RECOVERY ROAD MAP IN COLLABORATION WITH THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE MANAGEMENT 3 EXPERIMENTING WITH COMMUNITY-LED HABITAT RESTORATION PRACTICES TO SUSTAIN SPECIES RECOVERY IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE, INDIA ACTIVITIES 3.1 DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT EXPERIMENTAL HABITAT RESTORATION PLOTS ACROSS THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE 3.2 MONITOR AND EVALUATE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TO IDENTIFY THE BEST PRACTICES OF HABITAT RESTORATION IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING CONSERVATION OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS, PREY ANIMALS, HABITATS AND BIOLOGICAL CORRIDORS IN THE TRANSBOUNDARY MANAS LANDSCAPE, INDIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to sustain the recovery of tigers, co-predators and their prey across Transboundary Manas.Conservation Area of India. The objectives and associated activities are as follows: (1) Identifying the recovery potential for.tigers, co-predators and prey recovery in Manas Tiger Reserve; Activities: (1.1) Set baselines for population and community.structure of tigers, co-predators and prey in the Manas Tiger Reserve in India; (1.2) Build field and analytical capacity amongst.park management and grassroots NGO volunteers to conduct and analyze biological monitoring information for sustained.recovery; (2) Developing a collaborative conservation action plan to secure future tiger, co-predator and prey populations;.Activities: (2.1) Develop a tiger, co-predators and prey recovery road map in collaboration with the Manas Tiger Reserve.management; (3) Experimenting with community-led habitat restoration practices to sustain species recovery in Manas Tiger.Reserve, India; Activities: (3.1) Develop and implement experimental habitat restoration plots across the Manas Tiger Reserve;.(3.2) Monitor and evaluate restoration activities to identify the best practices of habitat restoration in Manas Tiger Reserve.

title.narrative: REDUCING THE ILLEGAL TRADE IN SOFTSHELL TURTLES IN WEST BENGAL - INDIA, USING AN INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE ILLEGAL SALE AND TRAFFICKING OF MEAT FROM SEVERAL SPECIES OF ENDANGERED SOFTSHELL TURTLES INCLUDING THE NARROW-HEADED SOFTSHELL TURTLE, INDIA SOFTSHELL TURTLE AND PEACOCK SOFTSHELL TURTLE WITHIN A HOTSPOT HOSTING SOME OF THE LARGEST MEAT MARKETS ALONG THE INDO-BANGLADESH BORDER. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING INTERVIEWS WITH INFORMANTS AND STAKEHOLDERS AND SYNTHESIZING AND ANALYZING THESE DATA, ALONG WITH TEN YEARS OF SEIZURE DATA, TO INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF DEMAND REDUCTION ACTIVITIES, AND 2) IMPLEMENTING DEMAND REDUCTION ACTIVITIES, LIKE BEHAVIOR CHANGE CAMPAIGNS.

title.narrative: STRENGHTEN THE PROTECTION MEASURES IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK AS A PART OF THE PROGRAM INDIAN RHINO VISION'

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE SALARY OF 15 ADDITIONAL GUARDS WHO ARE IN ADDITION TO THE EXISTING STAFF OF THE FOREST DEPARTMENT FOR 24 MONTHS, TO PATROL AND MONITOR THE RHINO HABITATS IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK MNP . PREFERENCE WILL BE GIVEN TO PERSONS FROM THE ADJACENT VILLAGES TO IMPROVE THE SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS OF THE VILLAGERS, AND TO DEVELOP A GOOD RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE MNP MANAGEMENT AND THE VILLAGERS ADJACENT TO MNP. SPECIAL TRAINING OF THE NEWLY RECRUITED GUARDS ON WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND TO COMBAT POACHING WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE FOREST DEPARTMENT.
